items.title: PyStdIsDeprecatedWarning doesnt show the caller line
items.body:
The output of this is like:
```
/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/py/_std.py:19: PyStdIsDeprecatedWarning: py.std is deprecated, plase import _pytestfixturefunction directly
  category=PyStdIsDeprecatedWarning)
```
It should instead show the line of the caller, not the line of the warning invocation.

items.title: [FeatureRequest] Add --doctest-only to only collect doctests
items.body: When using pytest on CI you often want to test doctests / unittests / intergration tests separately. To enable this usecase it would be good to have a `--doctest-only` flag to enable running on the doctests

items.title: pyimport raises ImportMismatchError
items.body:
Here's our case:

We run our build pipelines in Gitlab with Windows runners.

1) We create a Python virtual env using 'Gitlab runner A'. This will create a Python virtualenv with runner A's path hardcoded 'everywhere'. 

2) We save the virtual environment using Gitlab's artifacts.

3) We download the virtual env built under 'Gitlab runner A' and in certain cases, we use it under 'Gitlab runner B'. Because a) Python has the habit of using absolute paths in the venvs, and b) Gitlab uses different paths for each runner, to make the venv usable, we created a symlink named after the path for 'Gitlab runner A' and pointing to 'Gitlab runner B'.

4) Step 3 works in every situation we have encountered in the last year, except with pytest when we started using custom plugins. That context raises ImportMismatchError, even if the venv if fully functional; the check is purely nominal (path A is not equal to path B), whereas both paths work, because we have the symlink and the actual physical path.

COS:

- raise an error only when the functionality is actually broken ?
- have the possibility to ignore the error?
- do not ignore symlinks?

items.title: Maintenance mode, is there an alternative?
items.body:
Hi guys,

I just noticed that this library is not recommended for new projects anymore which is too bad since I quite like the features provided by `py.path`. So I'm wondering, what's the reasoning behind this? Is there an alternative library to use?

Especially in small shell scripts it can be far more convenient (and clearer) to do:
```python
path.join('something').write('some text', ensure=True)
```
Than writing:
```python
if not os.path.isdir(path):
    os.makedirs(path)

with open(os.path.join(path, 'something'), 'w') as fh:
    fh.write('some text')
```

items.title: Add parent and parents attributes
items.body:
I commonly have to access the parent multiple levels above a path, but the `py.path.local` module does not seem to have a convenient way to do it.

I would like to request / add two new attributes parent and parents which mirror the API of `pathlib`.
https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.PurePath.parents

items.title: Pylint complains about `from py.path import local`
items.body:
My code often uses an idiom `from py.path import local`:
```python
from py.path import local

def test_something():
    fname = local("tests/data.json")
    assert fname.exists()
```
All works well apart from pylint complaining:
```
E:  1, 0: No name 'path' in module 'py' (no-name-in-module)
E:  1, 0: Unable to import 'py.path' (import-error)
```

Is there any way to make pylint happier about that import?

items.title: make_numbered_dir breaks on case-sensitive filesystems
items.body:
in case of a case-miss-matched filesystem make_numbered_dir counts incorrectly

the solution would be to case-normalize the counting elements in order to find a correct maxnum
however we could also consider increment on errors

this issue causes pytest-dev/pytest#2323

items.title: Use the correct bugtrack_url
items.body:
The `bugtrack_url` field on PyPi is still pointing to the old issue tracker at https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/py/issues

From what it looks like this field can be set on PyPi only, it's not being picked up from `setup.py`.

Link to the latest release on PyPi: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/py/1.4.33

items.title: DeprecationWarning: 'U' mode is deprecated
items.body:
From python 3.4 on, the 'U' mode of [``open``](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#open) has been deprecated.
According to [this answer](http://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/a/298685/265868) the 'U' has been replaced by the ``newline`` argument, that when set to ``None``, the default, uses universal new line.
I have identified only three ``rU`` modes. Two in the [``readline``](https://github.com/pytest-dev/py/blob/master/py/_path/common.py#L170) function and one regarding [svn](https://github.com/pytest-dev/py/blob/master/py/_path/svnurl.py#L98).

- [x] If it's fine with you, for the first two cases I'll do a PR where I set the mode to ``rU`` for python 2 and ``r`` otherwise.
- [ ] I don't think that I need to touch the svn case, as the mode is never used

items.title: unittest.TestCase.assertWarns fails with py imported
items.body:
`unittest.TestCase.assertWarns()` fails with `RuntimeError` when `py` is imported.

This simple unit test:
```py
import unittest
import warnings

import pandas as pd  # imports py.* somewhere deep

class Case(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_assertWarns(self):
        with self.assertWarns(UserWarning):
            warnings.warn('Some warning')
```
when run with:
```bash
python -m unittest example.py
```
fails with:
```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_assertWarns (example.Case)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/example.py", line 9, in test_assertWarns
    with self.assertWarns(UserWarning):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/unittest/case.py", line 205, in __enter__
    for v in sys.modules.values():
RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration
----------------------------------------------------------------------
```

While I agree this is a [_unittest_ module issue](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/1288#issuecomment-167364150) (CPython [bug 29620](https://bugs.python.org/issue29620)), I should hope it can be more quickly resolved on the pylib's side.

Ref: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/1288

items.title: Encoding issue in python 2.7 with py 1.4.32
items.body:
Hello,

After an update from version `1.4.31` to `1.4.32`, the following sample test started failing:

```python
# coding: utf-8
from __future__ import unicode_literals


def test_non_ascii_dir_path():
    from py.path import local
    from tempfile import gettempdir

    path_a = gettempdir()
    path_b = 'ação'

    directory = local(path_a).join(path_b)
    directory.ensure(dir=1)
```

Output:
```
py.test test_path.py
============================= test session starts =============================
platform win32 -- Python 2.7.12, pytest-2.9.3.dev0, py-1.4.32, pluggy-0.3.1
rootdir: D:\tmp\path, inifile:
collected 1 items

test_path.py F

================================== FAILURES ===================================
___________________________ test_non_ascii_dir_path ___________________________

    def test_non_ascii_dir_path():
        from py.path import local
        from tempfile import gettempdir

        path_a = gettempdir()
        path_b = 'a├º├úo'

        directory = local(path_a).join(path_b)
>       directory.ensure(dir=1)

test_path.py:13:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
D:\Miniconda\envs\steve-env\lib\site-packages\py\_path\local.py:524: in ensure
    return p._ensuredirs()
D:\Miniconda\envs\steve-env\lib\site-packages\py\_path\local.py:503: in _ensuredirs
    if parent == self:
D:\Miniconda\envs\steve-env\lib\site-packages\py\_path\local.py:166: in __eq__
    s2 = fspath(other)
D:\Miniconda\envs\steve-env\lib\site-packages\py\_path\common.py:28: in fspath
    return path_type.__fspath__(path)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

self = local(u'c:\\users\\tnobrega\\appdata\\local\\temp\\a\xe7\xe3o')

    def __fspath__(self):
>       return str(self)
E       UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 38-39: ordinal not in range(128)
```

It looks like the relevant code was added in ef37a065f520d5122a (ping @aragilar, please have a look if you can), as an effort to backport `fspath` to pythons before 3.6. I am not sure how to fix this issue without breaking the py2 interface, and would like to start this discussion.

Thank you, and thanks for all your work.

items.title: py.path.local('/').join('tox.ini') produces '//tox.ini', causing pytest to hang on cygwin.
items.body:
The double slash path is causing problems, see https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/2135 for details.

This issue can be fixed by changing `strpath = strpath + sep + arg` to `strpath = strpath.rstrip(sep) + sep + arg` in `py.path.local.join()`

items.title: 'LocalPath' object is not iterable
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/76
- Originally reported by: @icemac
- Originally created at: 2016-02-22T17:27:29.339

LocalPath supports `read()` and `write()` but it lacks support for `__iter__()`  so it can be used like a file object returned by `open()`.

I came across this when using py.test for something like this:

```
#!python
def test_asdf(tmpdir):
    path = tmpdir.mkdir('sub').join('config.ini')
    path.write("[config]\na = b")
    configparser.ConfigParser().read_file(path)
```

items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/79

- Originally created at: 2016-04-28T15:06:17.320

https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/src/4617fe465cfc3289cefb8e7b8ce28ed5168f139f/py/_path/local.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#local.py-453

When trying to create a recursive directory I have to call to LocalPath.mkdir N times the level of directories I want to create creating intermediate LocalPath instances.

Also I'm lost at what is the use that LocalPath.mkdir will join all the args passed if it can't create recursive directories. (bug?)

Could be good that LocalPath.mkdir internally uses os.makedirs instead or for LocalPath to provide LocalPath.makedirs method.

Thanks

items.title: readlines(cr=False) returns a spurious empty string item at the end of the resulting list
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/77
- Originally reported by: @rogererens
- Originally created at: 2016-04-05T09:04:13.524

When the file contents ends with a eol-terminated string,
that string gets split up in 2 list items when readlines is called with argument cr is True.

You probably should insert a
content = content.rstrip()
before the
return content.split('\n')
in py/_path/common.py if you want to offer the functionality to remove newlines "from the end of each line".
Or, change the docstring to reflect the current code's functionality :-)

items.title: Breaks introspection of sys.modules by adding an object that raises when accessing __name__ into it
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/73
- Originally reported by: @ceridwen
- Originally created at: 2015-11-19T17:21:24.545

In py's `__init__.py`, it does this:

``` python
sys.modules['py.error'] = _apipkg.AliasModule("py.error", "py._error", 'error')
```

This object (`<AliasModule 'py.error' for 'py._error.error'>`) raises an AttributeError when you try to access its name:

``` python
    def __getattr__(self, name):
        if name[0] == "_":
            raise AttributeError(name) # This is where the raise occurs.
        eno = getattr(errno, name)
        cls = self._geterrnoclass(eno)
        setattr(self, name, cls)
        return cls
```

This violates the expectation that all modules should have a `__name__` set out in https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#the-standard-type-hierarchy .

items.title: py.code.Code "path" attribute not always a py.path.local object
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/71
- Originally reported by: @nicoddemus
- Originally created at: 2015-09-30T03:16:42.939

Sometimes the `path` attribute of a `py.code.Code` object is not a `py.local.path` object but a plain string, usually due to a traceback entry not being located in a real file but as a result of an exec statement.

``` python
import sys
def test_entry_not_path():
    try:
        ns = {}
        exec('def foo(): raise ValueError', ns)
        ns['foo']()
    except ValueError:
        _, _, tb = sys.exc_info()
    tb = py.code.Traceback(tb)
    assert isinstance(tb[-1].path, py.path.local)
```

This caused a regression in pytest, as seen in [#995](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/995).

items.title: Regression introduced in py.path.local.dirpath in 8e65cb5
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/62
- Originally reported by: @aldanor
- Originally created at: 2015-05-21T10:43:39.247

Due to the recent changes in 140e8d5, `py.path.local.dirpath` no longer passes keyword arguments to `py.path.local.join`, hence code like this becomes broken:

``` python
path.dirpath(*args, abs=True)
```

Suggestion: only use the optimization if no keyword arguments are provided, otherwise fall back to the original behaviour.

As reported in https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/tox/issue/252/tox-20-fails-with-in-path

running commands which are located in a path containing `&` characters (and most likely other) leads to errors because shell needs them to be escaped.

A simple `.replace('&', '\&'` fixes my problem but I am sure there is a better way.

items.title: On windows, common.FNMatcher doesn't match patterns containing posix path separators.
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/48
- Originally reported by: @christianmlong
- Originally created at: 2014-07-28T00:25:17.349

This bug occurs when running on windows, and the pattern has one or more posix path separators. 
## Steps to reproduce

On windows, do the following

```
mkvirtualenv winpathbug
pip install pytest mock
git checkout https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/sqlalchemy.git
py.test --collect-only -q
```

py.test finds no tests

```
============ test session starts ============
platform win32 -- Python 2.7.5 -- py-1.4.22 -- pytest-2.6.0
collected 0 items

============  in 0.90 seconds ============
```

Now, change setup.cfg

```
 [pytest]
 addopts= --tb native -v -r fxX
-python_files=test/*test_*.py
+python_files=test\\*test_*.py
```

Run py.test again

```
py.test --collect-only -q
```

With the windows-style path in setup.cfg, py.test now finds all the tests

```
============ test session starts ============
platform win32 -- Python 2.7.5 -- py-1.4.22 -- pytest-2.6.0
collected 6576 items
<Module 'test/aaa_profiling/test_compiler.py'>
  <Class 'CompileTest_sqlite_pysqlite'>
    <Instance '()'>
      <Function 'test_insert'>
      <Function 'test_select'>
. . .
      <Function 'test_where_empty'>

============  in 8.39 seconds ============
```
## Pull request

I have written a bug fix with a test.

The pull request changes common.FNMatcher so that it will match patterns containing posix path separators even on windows.

items.title: Can't handle standard unix ~ when using py.path.local()
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/44
- Originally reported by: Anonymous
- Originally created at: 2014-04-17T09:28:29.294

Hopefully the following repl session should explain the problem clearly; it originates from tox not being able to find the `python2.6` I had on my path. The codepath demonstrated is basically some relevant parts of `py.path.local.sysfind`.

I've had `~/bin` on my path for the better part of a year and nothing else has been unexpectedly broken from it.

```
Python 2.7.6 (default, Feb 26 2014, 12:07:17) 
[GCC 4.8.2 20140206 (prerelease)] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import py
>>> paths = py.std.os.environ['PATH'].split(':')
>>> paths
['/home/ivo/.virtualenvs/pypa/pip/bin', '~/bin', '/home/ivo/.rbenv/shims', '/home/ivo/.rbenv/bin', '/usr/local/sbin', '/usr/local/bin', '/usr/bin', '/opt/android-sdk/platform-tools', '/usr/bin/core_perl', '/home/ivo/.gem/ruby/2.0.0/bin', '/home/ivo/code/go/bin']
>>> paths[1]
'~/bin'
>>> py.path.local(paths[1])
local('/home/ivo/code/pypa/pip/~/bin')
>>>
```

items.title: forkedfunc skips exit handlers - breaks coverage in child process
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/45
- Originally reported by: @schlamar
- Originally created at: 2014-06-02T08:46:53.041

`py.process.ForkedFunc` is explicitly skipping exit handlers by calling `os._exit`. This breaks coverage's subprocess capturing.

Running the attached script reports the child line as missing because the coverage file of the child process is never saved to disk.

```
$ coverage run -p pyfork.py
2
$ coverage combine
$ coverage report -m
Name     Stmts   Miss  Cover   Missing
--------------------------------------
pyfork       9      1    89%   6
```

cc @ned

items.title: Broken w/Python 2.4: 'yield' not allowed in a 'try' block with a 'finally' clause
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/42
- Originally reported by: Anonymous
- Originally created at: 2014-03-01T01:51:05.510

Updating buildout updated py, which fails on 2.4:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_apipkg.py", line 124, in __makeattr
    result = importobj(modpath, attrname)
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_apipkg.py", line 47, in importobj
    module = __import__(modpath, None, None, ['__doc__'])
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_path/svnwc.py", line 401, in ?
    class SvnWCCommandPath(common.PathBase):
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_path/svnwc.py", line 822, in SvnWCCommandPath
    class Checkers(py.path.local.Checkers):
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_apipkg.py", line 124, in __makeattr
    result = importobj(modpath, attrname)
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_apipkg.py", line 47, in importobj
    module = __import__(modpath, None, None, ['__doc__'])
  File "/var/opt/zope210/plone3_dev/eggs/py-1.4.20-py2.4.egg/py/_path/local.py", line 533
     yield old
 SyntaxError: 'yield' not allowed in a 'try' block with a 'finally' clause
```

Looking at the commit history this change went into 1.4.16.  I pinned py=1.4.15 in my buildout and all is well again.  If python 2.4 is no longer supported, fine, but this should be documented, and mentioned to use 1.4.15.

Which Python versions are supported is confusing, because 7f37ee0 (1.4.10) removed 2.4 from install.txt, but the changelog for 1.4.12 mentions fixing Python 2.4.

items.title: TypeError: unorderable types str() < LocalPath()
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/35
- Originally reported by: @jaraco
- Originally created at: 2013-07-11T22:25:33.824

I encountered the error when running pytest on a project in Python 3. I'm using pytest 2.3.5 and py 1.4.15. The distilled error is apparent here:

```
>>> sorted(['foo', py.path.local()])
[local('C:\\Users\\jaraco\\G\\pan'), 'foo']
>>> sorted([py.path.local(), 'foo'])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unorderable types: str() < LocalPath()
```

I observed that LocalPath doesn't implement `__gt__`:

```
>>> py.path.local.__gt__
<slot wrapper '__gt__' of 'object' objects>
```

I was able to simply monkey-patch LocalPath to work around the error:

```
>>> py.path.local.__gt__ = lambda self, other: not (self < other or self == other)
>>> sorted([py.path.local(), 'foo'])
[local('C:\\Users\\jaraco\\G\\pan'), 'foo']
```

def break_next_test(tmpdir):

    subdir.chdir()

items.title: LocalPath.read returns incompatible types in Python2 vs Python3
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/19
- Originally reported by: [tpievila](http://bitbucket.org/tpievila)
- Originally created at: 2012-07-11T16:57:28.377

The docs say that read() should return a bytestring, but on Python3 it returns an unicode string. This breaks up Python3 builtins that expect a buffer interface. The read() does have a mode parameter, but this doesn't help when passing LocalPaths into library functions expecting normal builtin file objects.

A workaround is to use LocalPath.open('rb').

items.title: pylib (1.4.7 and trunk) fails tests with pypy-1.8
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/17
- Originally reported by: [marienz](http://bitbucket.org/marienz)
- Originally created at: 2012-06-06T11:34:41.535

When running the tests for py 1.4.7 or trunk (running py.test) with pypy 1.8 the following happens:
- test_apipkg.test_error_loading_one_element imports an "errorloading1" module that raises exceptions when used
- other tests (mostly path/test_local) use pickle
- pypy's modified pickle.py tries to build a map involving the id() of the **dict** of imported modules (from sys.modules), hits the "errorloading1" module, and fails

This is arguably mostly a pypy bug (why is its pickle looking at sys.modules at all, and why is it not coping with **dict** access failing?) but it can be worked around in the pylib testsuite by adding a try/finally: del sys.modules['errorloading1'] to test_apikpg.test_error_loading_one_element. This seems tidier (why keep the module that's specific to this test around in sys.modules?). I'll spare you the patch as I suspect there's some pypy-specific thing for this I don't know about, and it's obvious otherwise.

- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/16
- Originally reported by: @fbauer
- Originally created at: 2012-04-24T16:21:04.286

py.path.local.LocalPath.join calls str on its *args. This does not work for unicode filenames.

items.title: py._path.local.exists raises exception
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/15
- Originally reported by: @mattip
- Originally created at: 2012-03-25T07:56:09.727

The version of pylib used in pypy raises an exception in py._path.local.exists(r'd:\slave') on windows if d: is a cdrom and no cdrom is in the drive. This came up on a buildbot, the log is here http://buildbot.pypy.org/builders/pypy-c-jit-win-x86-32/builds/440/steps/translate/logs/stdio

items.title: Issues with text encoding
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/12
- Originally reported by: @the-allanc
- Originally created at: 2012-03-07T15:42:45.413

There's a bug which was introduced in py 1.4.5 which was affecting pytests which prints characters outside of expected text encodings.

There are some tests which deal with handling text encoded in different ways - some of that text gets printed out to stdout and py 1.4.5 isn't able to handle the text in the way that it could in 1.4.4.

Here's a paste of the error that I get:
http://a.libpa.st/s9TUK

I've also attached a test which reproduces the problem.

items.title: py._code.source.Source.getstatementrange(): UnboundLocalError
items.body:
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/pytest-dev/py/issue/7
- Originally reported by: [arfrever](http://bitbucket.org/arfrever)
- Originally created at: 2011-11-19T15:15:03.711

py._code.source.Source.getstatementrange() sometimes might raise "UnboundLocalError: local variable 'end' referenced before assignment". I use py 1.4.5.

```
>>> import py._code.source
>>> source = py._code.source.Source(":")
>>> source.getstatementrange(0)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/py/_code/source.py", line 142, in getstatementrange
    return start, end
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'end' referenced before assignment
```
